content: How can I help you today?

I’m here because my wife asked me to come. Things at home have been hard lately. My son’s been acting out, and it’s been causing a lot of tension between me and my wife. Honestly, I’m not even sure where to start.

It sounds like things have been really challenging at home, and it’s understandable to feel unsure about where to begin. It can be tough dealing with tension in the family, especially when it involves your son and your relationship with your wife. Can you tell me a bit more about what’s been going on or what feels most important to you right now?

Honestly, it feels like everything is falling apart. My son has been getting in trouble at school, having outbursts at home, and I can’t figure out how to help him. At the same time, my wife and I are arguing more, and it feels like we’re just growing further apart. I really just want to figure out how to fix all of this, but I don’t even know where to start.

It sounds like you’re carrying a heavy load right now—trying to support your son while also navigating challenges in your relationship with your wife. It seems like you truly care about your family and want things to improve, but the weight of everything happening at once is overwhelming. What do you think might help lighten that load, even just a little bit?

I honestly don’t know. I feel like I’ve tried everything I could think of—talking to my son, setting boundaries, trying to communicate better with my wife—but nothing seems to work. I just feel stuck, and it’s hard to see a way forward. I’m worried that I’m letting everyone down.

It sounds like you’ve been giving it your all to try to support your family—talking, setting boundaries, and working on communication—and it’s really tough feeling like those efforts aren’t paying off. It’s clear how deeply you care about your wife and son, and it’s natural to worry when things feel stuck. What’s been helping you get through this, even on the harder days?

Honestly, I’m not sure. It’s been hard to find things that help. I feel like I’m just going through the motions most days, trying to keep it together for my family, but I’m not really sure how to help myself right now.

It sounds like you’ve been doing everything you can to support your family, even though it’s been hard to focus on yourself in the process. That takes a lot of strength. It may feel like you’re just holding it all together, but it also shows how much you care. If you were to take a small moment for yourself, what might that look like?

I honestly don’t even know anymore. I feel so drained that I can’t even imagine what taking time for myself would look like. I just feel like if I step back or focus on me, everything else will fall apart even more.

It sounds like you’re feeling stretched so thin that the idea of taking time for yourself feels almost impossible—and there’s a fear that if you pause, it might make things worse. It’s clear how much you care about keeping things together for your family. What’s one small thing you think might help you feel just a little less drained, even if it’s something really simple?

I honestly don’t know. Even trying to think of something like that feels exhausting right now. I’ve been so focused on trying to keep everything going for my family that I’ve kind of forgotten how to take care of myself.

It sounds like you’ve been giving everything you have to your family and somewhere along the way, caring for yourself has taken a back seat. That can be really exhausting, and it’s not surprising that finding the energy to think about yourself feels like a challenge right now. What would it mean for you to start reconnecting with what you need, even in small steps?
I guess it would mean trying to remember what I used to enjoy or what made me feel better before everything got this overwhelming. But honestly, it’s hard to even imagine that right now.

It’s understandable that it feels difficult to imagine when things feel so overwhelming. Reflecting on what used to bring you some comfort or joy could be a place to start, even if it takes time. What’s one thing you used to do, no matter how small, that helped you feel more like yourself?

Maybe I used to enjoy going for a run or even just taking a long walk to clear my head. I haven’t done that in a while, though, because it feels like there’s always something else that needs my attention.

It sounds like running or walking used to be something that helped you find a little space to clear your head and take a breather. Even though it hasn’t felt possible recently, it’s still something that might be worth revisiting when the time feels right. What do you think would need to happen in order for you to make that small bit of time for yourself?
I guess I’d have to let go of the guilt of stepping away for a little while and trust that taking care of myself doesn't mean I’m neglecting my family. It’s just hard to believe that right now.

Letting go of that guilt sounds like it’s a big hurdle for you right now—feeling like stepping away doesn’t mean you’re letting your family down. It takes a lot of courage to even acknowledge that taking care of yourself might be part of helping them, too. What would it feel like to take just a few minutes for yourself, as a start, and see how it feels?

Letting go of that guilt sounds really challenging, especially when you’re so focused on supporting your family. But you’re absolutely right—taking care of yourself isn’t neglecting them. It might even give you more capacity to be there for them. Do you think you could try starting with a short walk, maybe even just five or ten minutes, and see how it feels?

Taking even a small step like a five- or ten-minute walk might feel more manageable and could give you a chance to test out how it feels to take some time for yourself. Would you like to explore what it might look like to fit that in—or is there something else on your mind that feels more important to talk about right now?
